subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: Transfering my recorded session to my computer
author: Wiliam Clarke
full_text:

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1

The link is not working

itcdeadpeople <ITCdeadpeople@...> wrote:          Hi Rees. This is a common item at Radio Shack. I think you are looking for 1/8" male 
connectors on both ends. It runs about $5. Do you have a store you can walk into? Here's 
one on eBay:

http://cgi.ebay.com/6ft-3-5mm-1-8-Male-Stereo-Audio-Patch-Cable-M-M-6-
ft_W0QQitemZ380016956958QQihZ025QQcategoryZ31492QQssPageNameZWDVWQQrdZ1
QQcmdZViewItem

And here's a Radio Shack link:

http://www.radioshack.com/product/index.jsp?
productId=2102970&cp=&sr=1&origkw=1%2F8+audio+patch+cable&kw=1%2F8+audio+
patch+cable&parentPage=search

Margaret

--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, Wiliam Clarke <reesclarke_69@...> wrote:
>
> I've looked for a patch cord for a couple of months
> 
> itcdeadpeople <ITCdeadpeople@...> wrote: Hi Kay. Just use the patch cord I 
described in my previous response ... connect it from the 
> headphone jack on the recorder to the mic jack on your computer. Open Audacity (or 
> whatever), hit the record button, then hit the play button on the recorder to play the 
> session into the computer. 
> 
> When you're done, press the stop button on the recording software, the stop button on 
> the recorder itself, and then save your session. From there, you can begin to work with 
it, 
> without worry of losing any data. Just be sure when you close the file DON'T SAVE 
> CHANGES on the original, so you always have the raw version to refer back to.
> 
> You can do this same thing with any recorder that has an earphone jack. Just go with the 
> one you are drawn to. There are a bunch of them on eBay. If you are doing sweep, you 
> don't even need a digital recorder, just plug in a mic into your computer and record on 
it. 
> This saves you all the time and hassle of moving the file from the recorder into your 
> computer. That's what I do. You really only need a digital recorder for traditional work 
or 
> portability (unless you have a laptop, which is pretty easy to take with you.) :-)
> 
> Margaret
> 
> --- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "psfponies" <psfponies@> wrote:
> >
> > Can anyone tell what would be the best way to transfer a session I 
> > recorded on an older microcassette recorder to my computer? 
> > 
> > I did my first recorded session last night. All went great except for 
> > the lousy reception. I didn't realize just how much you miss during a 
> > real time session when you play back what you recorded. 
> > 
> > I got two different Steve's one sounded Australian and a Mike. I also 
> > got the number "Seven" I am sure there is lots more there but my 
> > reception was so bad I can't hear everything.
> > 
> > Also what would be a good digital recorder (relatively cheap) to get 
> > that you can easily transfer to your computer?
> > 
> > Any help would be appreciated.
> > 
> > Kay
> >
>



                           

 between 0000-00-00 and 9999-99-99        
--0-1901875626-1208267767=:56936
Content-Type: text/html; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
